William Shakespeare.Action: Has a new play that Henslowe praises and uses as leverage to negotiate a loan and partnership.
The play title initially seems less serious ('Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter'), which may imply a less traditional or cautious approach, but the negotiation proceeds positively.
Practises his signature repeatedly, showing attention to detail and desire for perfection.
Becomes impatient while practising his signature, suggesting occasional frustration or lack of patience.
Patiently struggles with his boots while talking with Henslowe, showing focus rather than brusqueness.
Responds to Henslowe’s desperate inquiries with some poetic evasiveness but ultimately reassures him that the play is safe and underway.
Teases Henslowe about lacking a soul and thus not understanding the longing for a muse/soulmate.
Practices his signature repeatedly, showing dissatisfaction and impatience.
Responds evasively and poetically when pressured about the status of his play, stating the work is 'locked safe' inside his head and he is searching for his muse.
Strides purposefully along the street despite pressure, indicating some confidence and determination.
Negotiates with Henslowe about money owed and opportunities, but declines borrowing money despite potential partnership benefit.
Negotiates for his due payments and asserts his value as a writer despite financial struggle.
Proactively asks Henslowe for fifty pounds to become a partner in the Chamberlain's Men, seeking to advance his career beyond a hired player.
Is aware of the market demand shift from tragedy to comedy and shows some frustration but also adaptability.
Refuses Henslowe's implied suggestion to borrow money if he doubts success, showing pragmatism and confidence in his ability to progress on his own terms.
Gratefully makes a mental note of a harsh preacher's speech against theatres, showing openness and some appreciation for outside perspectives.
Keeps weekly confession with Dr. Moth, displaying a willingness to be vulnerable and introspective.
Lies silently about his personal life when asked if he lies with women, indicating reluctance to share truth and possible guardedness.
Admits to losing his creative gift and expresses vulnerability honestly.
Describes his marriage as distant and cold, implying emotional distance and lack of warmth there.
Admits openly to losing his creative gift and inability to write or love currently.
Engages thoughtfully and verbally with Dr. Moth about his emotional and creative block.
Reflects honestly on personal circumstances contributing to his creative block.
Looks at the snake bangle in wonder and asks if it will restore his gift.
Drops a sovereign into Dr. Moth's hand to buy the bracelet, demonstrating willingness to invest in his craft.
Walks straight past Henslowe towards the Palace at Whitehall, showing clear purpose and decisiveness.
Negotiates with Burbage to have him play the lead in the new play and confirms payment from Henslowe.
Claims to have received ten pounds from Henslowe, but Burbage disputes this, implying potential exaggeration or dishonesty.
Engages in witty banter and displays confidence in his upcoming comedy about a pirate and a romantic leading role.
Shows some defensiveness when questioned about his writing progress and the details of his play.
Agrees promptly and confidently to Burbage's deal to show the pages for two sovereigns, indicating readiness to negotiate and manage business.
Writes his name carefully and conceals it in the snake bangle, showing attention to detail and strategic thinking.
Does not react directly to the accusations of pickpocketing or the hostility around, instead maintaining focus on his work.
Slips a snake bracelet onto Rosaline's arm and shares an affectionate, intimate moment with her.
Expresses insecurity about losing his poetic gift to Rosaline in a sincere way.
Is distracted during a romantic moment by criticism from the audience, showing sensitivity.
Prepares his writing space with a specific ritual (spinning, rubbing hands, spitting) before writing, indicating focus and discipline.
Leaves the scene without explanation when Henslowe points out Viola knows the play by heart, showing possible avoidance or distraction.
Writing furiously all night, excited about his work, showing dedication and passion.
Nearly knocks down Henslowe leaving the house, showing lack of attention to others.
Shouts loudly and barges into Burbage's house without ceremony.
Reacts with shock and dismay to seeing Rosaline in bed with Mr. Tilney.
Writing furiously all night, producing ten pages, and confidently presenting them as a man with a mission.
Interrupting Henslowe and declaring 'God, I'm good!' with obvious self-assurance about his work.
Bangs on Burbage's door without ceremony, indicating informal, direct approach.
Charges into a bedroom unexpectedly and catches the Master of the Revels with Rosaline, leading to personal embarrassment.
Thrusts the pages of his play into the coals and watches them burn, showing emotional distress.
Responds briefly and somewhat dismissively to Tilney and Rosaline, turning away and speaking curtly.
Insists on paying for his and Marlowe's drinks, showing generosity and friendliness.
Remains behind alone, appears aghast and troubled about his situation, indicating vulnerability but no direct warmth to others in this moment.
Compliments Marlowe's earlier work sincerely.
Admits openly that he has not written a word of his new play idea.
Engages thoughtfully and listens attentively to Marlowe's story suggestions.
Exhibits a despondent sigh and helpless gesture, implying insecurity but not friendliness or tolerance in this moment.
Admits honestly he has not written a word of his new play yet, showing self-awareness about his current progress.
Engages thoughtfully and constructively with Marlowe to develop a story idea, indicating creative collaboration and intellectual engagement.
Appears despondent and hesitant about his new play, suggesting some lack of confidence or procrastination.
In response to Marlowe's confusion, makes a helpless gesture and quickly moves on, indicating some evasiveness or lack of preparation about his work.
Looks at Henslowe in outrage when Henslowe praises an actor with a stutter insincerely.
Sits brooding alone, silently expressing hope and anxiety.
Responds to actor reciting his lines with curiosity and captivation, attempts to engage sincerely by asking to see the actor's face, shows openness and interest.
Interrupts the actor mid-speech somewhat abruptly and insists he take off his hat, causing the actor to panic and run off.
Recognizes his own speech and is captivated by the actor performing it; confidently interrupts to engage and demands to see the actor's face.
Shows bewilderment when the actor panics and runs offstage, but quickly follows, indicating adaptability and pursuit of important matters.
Shouts to find the boy, shows urgency and focus in a crowded room.
Engages briefly and politely with Wabash, who shakes his hand excitedly.
Challenges the boatman to follow another boat, showing determination.
Waits patiently outside the kitchen door after delivering his letter despite dismissive treatment and near getting soaked by servant.
Introduces himself politely and respectfully when asking for Viola.
Introduces himself confidently as an actor, poet, and playwright at the kitchen door and waits patiently despite being treated roughly.
Hops nimbly aside to avoid getting soaked by water thrown carelessly by a servant.
Joins musicians and strums competently, helps himself to a snack despite orders that musicians don't eat.
Is entranced and sincere in his adoration of Viola, trying to speak but overwhelmed by emotion.
Insinuates himself gently into the dance to keep Viola in view, showing respectful interest.
Insinuates himself into the dance to keep close to Viola, demonstrating persistence and social agility.
Is rendered speechless and unable to speak despite being addressed by Viola, showing nervousness and loss of composure.
Expresses admiration for Viola's beauty sincerely and openly.
Approaches Viola tenderly and with a gentle whisper, signaling respect and affection.
Responds humbly when Viola compliments his work, admitting his lowly status.
Uses Christopher Marlowe's name to avoid danger, indicating quick thinking but a self-preserving omission.
Expresses love openly to Viola despite danger, shows sincere affection.
Attempts to evade capture by climbing tree but still faces consequences; shows vulnerability and persistence.
Recognizes his own status as both poet and lowly player, shows self-awareness.
Attempts to sneak up to the balcony by climbing a tree but is caught by the Nurse and falls out.
Escapes detection by dropping safely out of sight from the garden wall.
Works late into the night, very productive and inspired, filling many sheets with writing.
Shakes hands enthusiastically with new actors joining the company, welcoming them into the play.
Calmly responds to a sudden, boisterous interruption with focus and resumes directing the casting of roles amidst chaos.
Confidently identifies a role (Mercutio) and offers it to the prominent new actor Ned Alleyn, showing quick thinking and strategic casting.
Greets actors warmly and playfully, shows concern for Sam Gosse's health by noticing her hoarse voice and cold.
Turns away when suspicion arises about Sam's cold, showing possible avoidance of confrontation.
Encourages the urchin John Webster with kind words and shows interest in him and the stray cat,
Shows concern for Sam Gosse's voice and well-being, indicating attentiveness and responsibility towards his actors.
Turns away when suspecting Sam is lying about her cold, possibly indicating avoidance or lack of confrontation.
Responds politely and neutrally to Fennyman's praise of Marlowe, showing restraint and professionalism.
Arrives in a hurry looking for Thomas but finds no one, then gives up and turns away, showing some level of frustration or resignation but also adaptability.
Engages thoughtfully with the urchin John Webster about Titus Andronicus, showing interest in new talent and understanding of dramatic themes.
Backs away unnerved by the urchin's behavior, showing discomfort rather than engagement.
Observes the rehearsal quietly and supports the actors with positive brief feedback ('Good').
Recognizes the scene on stage and gives a direction to Henslowe to 'Cut round him for now.'
Appears unnerved and quickly wants to leave the interaction with the urchin ('I have to get back')
Watches and listens attentively to the actors performing his lines, appreciating the delivery ('Good').
Interrupts rehearsal with a light joke about not spending all the money at once.
Expresses frustration sharply at interruptions during rehearsal.
Encourages actor Ned Alleyn to take care of the Mercutio scene, showing trust and delegation.
Ignores Henslowe's comment about writing a sonnet instead of a play, showing disengagement or dismissiveness.
Preempts Ned Alleyn’s criticism by engaging him respectfully and explaining his work with enthusiasm.
Displays private superstition rituals alone before writing (spins, rubs hands, spits).
Hurries past Burbage without stopping despite greeting and request, showing disregard or preoccupation.
Calls out to Viola (in disguise as Thomas) from a distance asking about a letter, indicating concern and effort to communicate.
Preempts Ned Alleyn's criticism by confidently explaining the quality of the speech and the passionate duel scene he wrote, demonstrating control and confidence in his work.
Has a personal ritual before writing (spins, rubs hands, spits), showing thoughtful preparation and superstition that may aid his focus.
Rushes past Burbage without stopping, prioritizing urgency over social interaction, suggesting dedication but possibly poor communication or disregard for collaboration.
Collapses in pain and openly expresses vulnerability after reading the painful letter.
Turns on boatman savagely when addressed, showing irritability and brusqueness.
Engages in intimate, sincere conversation with Viola despite risk of being overheard, showing trust and openness.
Reads the painful letter and expresses deep emotional vulnerability openly.
Turns savagely on the boatman and commands him to row away, asserting control of the situation.
Engages in an intimate and somewhat strategic conversation with Viola despite distractions, showing emotional intelligence and focus.
Expresses confusion and emotional turmoil about what to do, showing indecisiveness in a critical moment.
Speaks eloquently about the beauty and qualities of his lady, showing literary skill and confidence in his poetic expressions.
Expresses fervent belief in love transcending social boundaries, demonstrating passionate conviction and personal courage.
Takes a bold social risk by openly declaring his love despite class differences and potential danger from rivals like Lord Wessex.
Holds Viola close after bumping into her, showing immediate physical support and concern.
Concerned about Viola being a maid and the consequences, shows care and respect.
Passionately kisses Viola and engages sincerely, showing openness and sincere affection.
Sneaks into Viola's garden and bedroom without prior consent, invading privacy.
Tenderly undresses Viola and respectfully discovers her bandaged bosom, then spins her naked with care.
Lies in Viola's arms after making love, engaging in gentle affectionate conversation and kisses.
Successfully courts Viola with confidence and affection, displaying emotional intelligence and skill in intimate interaction.
Is startled to find Viola bandaged but proceeds attentively and confidently, showing adaptability.
Kisses Viola affectionately and tries to stay in bed with her despite morning responsibilities, softly arguing to delay leaving.
Uses gentle, playful deception about the morning rooster to prolong intimate moment with Viola.
Insists on leaving early in the morning to attend to duties despite Viola's attempts to keep him, showing a sense of responsibility and prioritization.
Tries to convince Viola it is still night (the owl vs. the rooster) to stay longer in bed, showing playful persuasion but also a form of evasiveness regarding his commitments.
Ultimately yields to Viola's insistence, delaying his work and potentially putting responsibility second to personal desire.
Watches the rehearsal attentively and reacts strongly to what he perceives as an incorrect portrayal, interrupting the rehearsal to suggest a correction.
Engages sincerely and warmly in a moment of intimacy and connection with Viola during the rehearsal, sharing a genuine kiss and showing openness.
Laughs off and withdraws apologetically when Alleyn sarcastically challenges him, indicating humility and tolerance to teasing by colleagues.
Retreats to the shadows backstage, appearing agitated and alone during a rehearsal, suggesting internal struggle and potential withdrawal from engagement.
Kisses Viola's hand and shares a secret, tender moment with her backstage, showing intimacy and affection.
Pulls away reluctantly from Viola after a dangerous backstage kiss, showing some restraint and sensitivity.
Races up to his writer's corner eagerly, displaying passion for his work but no interpersonal warmth in this moment.
Shares intimate moments with Viola, reading lines together and responding playfully to her kisses.
Writes beautiful and memorable lines such as 'But soft, what light through yonder window breaks? It is the east and Juliet is the sun.' and demonstrates command over poetic expression.
Manages to keep focus on reading and sharing his work even while being distracted by Viola's kisses.
Undressed, strides around the room feeding Juliet's lines to Viola in bed, actively supporting and coaching her.
Coaches Viola thoroughly on Juliet's lines, demonstrating dedication and understanding of the text.
Continuing rehearsal late into the night by torchlight, showing commitment and focus on quality.
Thanks Ned courteously and calls him a gentleman despite their ironic exchange.
Engages in ironic, somewhat harsh banter calling Ned 'a Warwickshire shit-house.'
Calms Viola when she is anxious and speaks reflectively about the nature of his play's story and its themes, showing thoughtful understanding of his work.
Appears uncertain or resigned about the outcome of his play, acknowledging it is not a comedy and that fate is unchangeable, indicating awareness but a lack of control over external factors.
Expresses protective concern for Viola, refusing to let her act recklessly for the Queen, offers to accompany her despite danger.
Acknowledges the harsh reality of his social position and desires but still wishes well for Viola, showing sincerity.
Expresses deep awareness of social realities and personal desires, showing internal conflict about pursuing love given social constraints.
Insists on accompanying Viola despite the danger posed by Wessex, demonstrating boldness and confidence.
Engages in argument but does not find a clear resolution or alternative plan, indicating some lack of strategic thinking.
Imitates a country accent and humorously assumes the role of Viola's chaperone, engaging Wessex playfully and supporting Viola.
Watches the Queen with fascination and listens carefully to the conversation, showing genuine interest but does not interrupt or impose.
Touched by Viola's outburst defending playwrights' ability to portray true love.
Surprises court by boldly offering fifty pounds to wager on whether a play can show true love.
Confidently offers a fifty pounds wager on his belief that a play can show the true nature of love, despite the shock and horror of the court.
Leaps up to confront the attackers, defends himself and others during the brawl.
Describes the fight as a 'literary feud' in a somewhat dismissive or casual manner.
Leaps onto the stage amid a brawl and actively parries an attack using a stave taken from an actor, swinging back at the aggressor.
Refers to the brawl as 'a literary feud. Quite normal.' showing wit and calm in chaos.
Is eventually smashed over the head and falls off the stage.
Shoves Viola into the hiding place under the stage and tells her to stay hidden, protecting her from danger.
Embraces and kisses Viola tenderly, showing intimacy and care.
Shoves Viola into the space under the stage (Hell) and tells her to stay hidden, then returns confidently to the chaotic fight on stage.
Uses the open trap door to dive down into the hidden space where Viola is, showing awareness of stage mechanics and timing.
Sits Viola down and makes her feel included in the company; encourages her to have a drink and enjoy herself despite the disreputable setting
Grabs and rejects Poxy Pol in a curt, possessive manner to protect his investment
Invites Fennyman to join his play, giving him a small but vital role.
Looks at Viola helplessly when she is upset, tries to say something but does not.
Offers a role to Fennyman enthusiastically, demonstrating inclusivity and encouragement.
Admits he does not know the plot or how the play ends when questioned by Henslowe.
Looks helplessly at Viola and fails to respond effectively when she ducks away in tears.
Stands horror-stricken and mourns deeply upon hearing of Marlowe's death, expressing guilt and sorrow openly.
Prays, weeps, and bangs his head in private grief, showing sincere emotional pain and vulnerability.
Tries to follow Viola but is physically restrained by Peter.
Responds with horror upon hearing of Marlowe's death and blames himself, showing deep emotional turmoil.
Falls into a puddle and staggers on the street, overwhelmed and distraught.
Seeks solitude in a church to pray and grieve, showing introspection and attempt at processing his emotions.
Staggers out of church haunted by guilt, honestly confesses to Viola that he has killed a man.
Raises a quivering accusatory finger at Wessex, confronting him and causing Wessex to flee in terror.
Confronts Wessex with an accusatory finger despite his disheveled, weakened state, causing Wessex to break down and flee.
Appears spectral, bedraggled, bleeding, and ravaged, showing physical and emotional weakness and disarray.
Admits to Viola that he believes he has killed a man, indicating honesty and self-awareness.
Lies on his back, sobered and full of guilt, seemingly immobilized by his emotions.
Admits he cannot marry Viola due to social constraints but honestly expresses his love for her.
Engages in sincere and passionate exchange of feelings with Viola, including kisses and declaration of love.
Expresses frustration at Viola's potential marriage to Wessex, showing his concern for her and himself.
Acknowledges personal deception in the relationship, showing vulnerability and self-awareness.
Shares the manuscript eagerly and includes the entire company in the reading, engages with actors by assigning parts and explaining the plot, showing collaborative and inclusive behavior.
Maintains intense focus on the work and seems somewhat withdrawn or distracted, staring at Viola silently rather than engaging verbally in the moment.
Leads the company through the complex plot of Romeo and Juliet with clear understanding and intense focus, assigning roles and explaining the story to actors confidently.
Appears distracted or less focused when staring at Viola during the rehearsal, momentarily neglecting the scene discussion.
Gives Viola a neatly written manuscript of his play as a present, shows her the new scene, reads it aloud tenderly.
Has a neatly written manuscript of his play prepared and presents it with confidence to Viola.
Recites the new scene from memory smoothly and fluently, demonstrating his skill and knowledge of his work.
Uses the words of the play as a subtle and meaningful way to express farewells, showing emotional intelligence and creative skill.
Engages in a violent sword fight with Wessex, showing passionate rage and merciless look.
Steps back and sinks to his knees, expressing relief at being free from a troublesome situation.
Stares helplessly at Viola when Webster accuses him of knowing her secret, showing no defense or betrayal.
Shakes his head to indicate that this cannot be the end after Viola apologizes, showing hope and concern.
Does not expose or condemn Viola despite her deception being revealed, allowing her to leave silently and alone.
Is paralysed and helpless when exposed and accused during a crisis.
Shows emotional restraint and steadiness by shaking his head and refusing to accept defeat after the theatre is closed.
Fails to avoid a physical attack (a sock to the jaw by Ned Alleyn) and falls down in the dust.
Present among the company in a moment of despair and drinking to drown sorrows, showing lack of agency in crisis.
Burbage declares support for Shakespeare by offering the theatre Curtain for Shakespeare's play, showing confidence in Shakespeare's work and his position within the theatre world.

No direct action from Shakespeare is shown in this excerpt; his competence is implied by the respect and resources given to him by others rather than direct demonstrations of skill or confidence here.
Walks on without looking at the poster advertising his play and does not respond when called by Henslowe, showing no engagement or acknowledgment of the professional opportunity.
Pushes through crowds purposefully on his way to the river and climbs down to waiting boats, demonstrating decisiveness and focused action.
Runs across the grass eagerly toward the house, watches carriage with distant, possibly contemplative expression
Recognizes the poor performance of the actor Wabash and expresses concern that they are lost.
Shuts his eyes and prays backstage before the performance begins, indicating a lack of active control at that moment.
Wish Sam luck despite poor performance, tries to maintain composure.
Appears indifferent or overwhelmed ('absently'), shows frustration but does not harshly blame Sam.
Wishes Sam Gosse luck despite obvious poor performance, tries to encourage him.
Reacting with dismay and discomfort to Sam's poor line delivery backstage.
Asks for a line from Sam to assess the problem, shows active engagement with the issue.
Accepts uncertain advice from Henslowe about continuing the show despite a major problem, showing limited control over the situation.
Covers his ears and cowers in dread anticipation before the performance.
Cowers in dread anticipation, covering his ears before hearing Viola's voice on stage.
Turns in amazement at the sound of Viola’s voice, showing openness to unexpected input and adaptation.
Encourages fellow actor playing Mercutio with the words 'Courage man. The hurt cannot be much.'
Shows a moment of vulnerability and acceptance after the fight by admitting 'I am fortune's fool.'
Performs an intense and real portrayal of Romeo, effectively conveying deep emotion and engaging the audience silently and attentively.
Breathless from fight scene but maintains composure backstage, showing dedication and focus.
Freely admits 'I am fortune's fool,' indicating awareness of fate but possibly implying lack of control over circumstances.
Recognizes the gravity of Viola's silence after asking if she is married and remains motionless, showing awareness and emotional insight.
Stops speaking as Romeo after Viola as Juliet's lines, indicating possible hesitation or emotional overwhelm.
Performs the death scene of Romeo with genuine tenderness and shares a touching, tearful moment of eye contact with Viola, demonstrating sincere emotional connection.
Performs the role of Romeo with visible emotional depth and conviction, evoking a genuine moment between himself and Viola, indicating skill and emotional intelligence in acting.
Delivers complex, poetic lines with confidence and expressiveness, demonstrating mastery over his own work and theatrical performance.
Performs the final, emotionally charged scene as Romeo, delivering the tragic death moment convincingly and raising the fatal drug in a last toast.
Is part of a performance eliciting strong emotional responses from the audience, including weeping whores and the nurse, indicating effective storytelling and impact.
Embraces and kisses Viola passionately in farewell on stage, sharing an intimate moment openly.
Responds to the Queen’s direct attention with confident composure, suggesting skill and assurance before and during public performance.
Allows the Queen to interrupt and take control of the situation without protest, showing deference but not a lack of authority or understanding.
No evident hesitation or confusion before the Queen addresses him, indicating preparedness and presence of mind.
Bows deeply to the Queen after her invitation to come to Greenwich and talk further.
Remains silent and passive during the exchange about the wager and the Queen's comments after the play.
Admits he has hurt Viola and expresses sorrow.
Harshly rejects the idea of writing a comedy and expresses bitterness about his hero and heroine's fates.
Engages sincerely and collaboratively with Viola on developing the story despite his bitterness.
Accepts fifty pounds for his work showing professional recognition and is encouraged to write again by Viola.
Expresses deep personal disappointment and states 'I am done with theatre,' showing a momentary loss of confidence and withdrawal from his profession.
Engages in a collaborative creative process with Viola to develop ideas for the Queen's requested comedy, demonstrating intellectual engagement and skill.
Harshly dismisses the idea of writing a comedy and cynically describes his hero and heroine, revealing bitterness and a pessimistic outlook.
Despite his bitterness, he actively contributes constructive story elements like naming Orsino and recognizing dramatic potential, illustrating creative competence.
Expresses deep, sincere love and devotion to Viola, saying she will never age, fade, or die for him, and calls her his love a thousand times goodbye.
Writes a play inspired by Viola's strength and spirit, framing her as a heroic figure and soulmate.
Shows skill in beginning a new play with creative, vivid imagery and constructs an engaging narrative voice.
Demonstrates emotional sensitivity and confidence in capturing the depth of his feelings through writing, indicating artistic competence.
No signs of hesitation or writer's block; starts writing decisively and clearly.
